discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. precise filter to allow only HTTP traffic

ARP will not be blocked

Selected Answer: B
contract is only for unicast traffic scope, ARP is always flooded at the BD level if both EPGs are in the same BD level. Correct answer is B.

B appears to be the right answer as per slide 35 below. 
https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/emea/docs/2020/pdf/BRKACI-3004.pdf

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. What must be configured in the service graph to redirect HTTP traffic between the EPG client and EPG server to go through the Cisco ASA firewall?

choices.B: precise filter to allow only HTTP traffic
choices.A: contract filter to allow ARP and HTTP

discussion.content:
D is the correct answer! Though the SSH filter entry has a lower priority, it will still be executed first.. Deny actions and protocol ( SSH ) wins over filter priority.
Also 'apply both directions' and reverse filter port should be checked..

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/data-center-virtualization/application-centric-infrastructure/white-paper-c11-743951.html

comments.content:
D makes your SSH deny less eficient than your allow line, so it would be allowed either way. 
If you go with C, your traffic may go one way, but you wont get reply, so in the end it wonÂ´t work either

discussion.content:
All_noSSH contract to allow all IP traffic except SSH 
except SSH = deny 
allow all IP traffic = allow 

I too go with C

I think C is correct too, Priority become greyed if selected, so option A and B could not be, destination ports should not be swapped at source ports on provider EPG, (no need for provider EPG to answer) hence... Reverse Filter Ports should be disabled. denying SSH is a priority.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Two application profiles are configured in the same tenant and different VRFs. Which contract scope is configured to allow communication between the two application profiles?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
same tenant and different VRFs

D is correct 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/data-center-virtualization/application-centric-infrastructure/white-paper-c11-743951.html

Contract scope
Tenant: A contract will program rules between EPGs that are defined within the same tenant. If there are EPGs tied to multiple VRFs within a single tenant, and they consume/provide the same contract, this scope can be used to allow inter-VRF communication.

Agree A 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/dcn/whitepapers/cisco-application-centric-infrastructure-design-guide.html#_Toc129073596

Understanding the Bidirectional and Reverse Filter Options

Selected Answer: A
This document states that you must enable "Apply both direction" for reverse filter port to become available. So C is nonsense - it is absolutely A.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/dcn/whitepapers/cisco-application-centric-infrastructure-design-guide.html#Understandingthebidirectionalandreversefilteroptions

choices.A: Apply Both Direction ENABLED and Reverse Port Filter ENABLED
choices.C: Apply Both Direction DISABLED and Reverse Port Filter ENABLED
choices.B: Apply Both Direction DISABLED and Reverse Port Filter DISABLED
choices.D: Apply Both Direction ENABLED and Reverse Port Filter DISABLED

choices.A: Set the subnet scope to Shared Between VRFs
choices.C: Change the contract scope to Tenant
choices.E: Export the contract and import as a contract interface
choices.B: Enable Advertise Externally under the subnet scope
choices.D: Change the subject scope to VRF

discussion.content: A and C correct, B is for l3out, D is not gonna help between VRFs and E is in between tenants

Selected Answer: AC
A. Set the subnet scope to Shared Between VRFs
C. Change the contract scope to Tenant
for inter vrf

Selected Answer: AC
AC it is
